The purposes of the program are as follows:
To use covered programs to accomplish purposes and functions similar to those of the following programs, as in effect on September 30, 2013:
The agricultural water enhancement program established under
The Chesapeake Bay watershed program established under
The cooperative conservation partnership initiative established under
The Great Lakes basin program for soil erosion and sediment control established under
To further the conservation, restoration, and sustainable use of soil, water, wildlife, and related natural resources on eligible land on a regional or watershed scale.
To encourage eligible partners to cooperate with producers in—
meeting or avoiding the need for national, State, and local natural resource regulatory requirements related to production on eligible land; and

implementing projects that will result in the carrying out of eligible activities that affect multiple agricultural or nonindustrial private forest operations on a local, regional, State, or multi-State basis.

means any of the following conservation activities:

text.#text: Water quality or quantity conservation, restoration, or enhancement projects relating to surface water and groundwater resources, including—
the conversion of irrigated cropland to the production of less water-intensive agricultural commodities or dryland farming; or
irrigation system improvement and irrigation efficiency enhancement.

text.#text: with respect to water and waste disposal direct and guaranteed loans provided under
maximizing the use of loan guarantees to finance eligible projects in rural communities where the population exceeds 5,500;
maximizing the use of direct loans to finance eligible projects in rural communities where the impact on rate payers will be material when compared to financing with a loan guarantee;
establishing and applying a materiality standard when determining the difference in impact on rate payers between a direct loan and a loan guarantee;

text.#text: A center of excellence is composed of 1 or more of the eligible entities specified in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that provide financial or in-kind support to the center of excellence.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: subsection (b)(7) of the Competitive, Special, and Facilities Research Grant Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Competitive, Special, and Facilities Research Grant Act/ss:b/p:7

text.#text: The criteria for consideration to be recognized as a center of excellence shall include efforts—
to ensure coordination and cost effectiveness by reducing unnecessarily duplicative efforts regarding research, teaching, and extension;
to leverage available resources by using public/private partnerships among agricultural industry groups, institutions of higher education, and the Federal Government;
to implement teaching initiatives to increase awareness and effectively disseminate solutions to target audiences through extension activities; and
to increase the economic returns to rural communities by identifying, attracting, and directing funds to high-priority agricultural issues.

Where practicable, the criteria for consideration to be recognized as a center of excellence shall include efforts to improve teaching capacity and infrastructure at colleges and universities (including land-grant institutions, schools of forestry, schools of veterinary medicine, and NLGCA Institutions).

header.#text: Revision of strategic plan for forest inventory and analysis

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall revise the strategic plan for forest inventory and analysis initially prepared pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013/s:8401/ss:b

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to address the requirements imposed by

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3(e) of the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act of 1978
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act of 1978/s:3/ss:e

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall describe in detail the organization, procedures, and funding needed to achieve each of the following:

text.#text: In revising the strategic plan, the
Complete the transition to a fully annualized forest inventory program and include inventory and analysis of interior Alaska.

Implement an annualized inventory of trees in urban settings, including the status and trends of trees and forests, and assessments of their ecosystem services, values, health, and risk to pests and diseases.
Report information on renewable biomass supplies and carbon stocks at the local, State, regional, and national level, including by ownership type.

Engage State foresters and other users of information from the forest inventory and analysis in reevaluating the list of core data variables collected on forest inventory and analysis plots with an emphasis on demonstrated need.
Improve the timeliness of the timber product output program and accessibility of the annualized information on that database.
Foster greater cooperation among the forest inventory and analysis program, research station leaders, and State foresters and other users of information from the forest inventory and analysis.
Promote availability of and access to non-Federal resources to improve information analysis and information management.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to integrate remote sensing, spatial analysis techniques, and other new technologies in the forest inventory and analysis program.

text.#text: Understand and report on changes in land cover and use.

Expand existing programs to promote sustainable forest stewardship through increased understanding, in partnership with other Federal agencies, of the over 10 million family forest owners, their demographics, and the barriers to forest stewardship.
Implement procedures to improve the statistical precision of estimates at the sub-State level.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit the revised strategic plan to the

Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate

header.#text: Ensuring high standards for agency use of scientific information

text.#text: Not later than January 1, 2014, each Federal agency shall have in effect guidelines for ensuring and maximizing the quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of scientific information relied upon by such agency.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , with respect to a Federal agency, shall ensure that—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013/s:12307/ss:a

text.#text: when scientific information is considered by the agency in policy decisions—
the information is subject to well-established scientific processes, including peer review where appropriate;
the agency appropriately applies the scientific information to the policy decision;
except for information that is protected from disclosure by law or administrative practice, the agency makes available to the public the scientific information considered by the agency;

the agency gives greatest weight to information that is based on experimental, empirical, quantifiable, and reproducible data that is developed in accordance with well-established scientific processes; and

with respect to any proposed rule issued by the agency, such agency follows procedures that include, to the extent feasible and permitted by law, an opportunity for public comment on all relevant scientific findings;

the agency has procedures in place to make policy decisions only on the basis of the best reasonably obtainable scientific, technical, economic, and other evidence and information concerning the need for, consequences of, and alternatives to the decision; and

the agency has in place procedures to identify and address instances in which the integrity of scientific information considered by the agency may have been compromised, including instances in which such information may have been the product of a scientific process that was compromised.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that have been approved by the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013/s:12307/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy

text.#text: No policy decision issued after January 1, 2014, by an agency subject to this section may take effect prior to such date that the agency has in effect guidelines under

header.#text: Approval needed for policy decisions To take effect

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , a policy decision of an agency that does not comply with guidelines approved under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013/s:12307/ss:d/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be deemed to be arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and otherwise not in accordance with law.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013/s:12307/ss:c

text.#text: This subsection shall not apply to policy decisions that are deemed to be necessary because of an imminent threat to health or safety or because of another emergency.
